title: Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content (2007): Fourth Grade
subject: Science (2009-2012)

document.title: Science Grade 4 Assessment Anchors and Eligible Content

06C2AE7F701F4E018042BF73F25C8B7C.description:
Describe the causes of seasonal
change as they relate to the
revolution of Earth and the tilt of
Earth’s axis.

600B64657A884B7983AD10D3EF37389B.description:
Explain how the motion of the Sun -
Earth - Moon system relates to time
(e.g., days, months, years).

17712EF582CE4CB2BC17F1E05BD56E03.description:
Describe motions of the Sun - Earth -
Moon system.

1EED3542629140CD9314CC81CF1B9732.description:
Describe Earth’s relationship to the Sun
and the Moon.
Reference: 3.4.4.D

43CE5C92A83D46D1B2CF96E680BFBE61.description: Composition and Structure of the Universe

0932205905F44A68852A068BCE4D80BB.description:
Identify appropriate instruments (i.e.,
thermometer, rain gauge, weather vane,
anemometer, and barometer) to study
weather and what they measure.

A8EC60DC3C3849A2B1A7146BAE88D38A.description:
Identify weather patterns from data charts
or graphs of the data (e.g., temperature,
wind direction, wind speed, cloud types,
precipitation).

9CB03D75208F4A728BC554782F62A963.description:
Identify basic cloud types (i.e., cirrus,
cumulus, stratus, and cumulonimbus) and
make connections to basic elements of
weather (e.g., changes in temperature,
precipitation).

2E889C58F3B8444D85009E606F4DDB04.description:
Identify basic weather conditions and
how they are measured.
Reference: 3.5.4.C, 3.7.4.B, 3.2.4.B

5AAE5B99D9A5444EA89CC2280F0AA9BE.description:
Explain the role and relationship of a
watershed or a wetland on water sources
(e.g., water storage, groundwater
recharge, water filtration, water source,
water cycle).

0D0B2DE0A5294937B4EE94F51422F717.description:
Describe or compare lentic systems (i.e.,
ponds, lakes, and bays) and lotic systems
(i.e., streams, creeks, and rivers).

5EE7CF9A57BD437DA8B1A72ED3AD8B88.description:
Explain how water goes through phase
changes (i.e., evaporation, condensation,
freezing, and melting).

8C139832C1DC44FDAB158A3ECCEAFD0C.description:
Describe types of freshwater and
saltwater bodies (e.g., lakes, rivers,
wetlands, oceans).

6A982EC51D4C422E8FFFCD64E363D2D5.description:
Describe Earth’s different sources of
water or describe changes in the form
of water.
Reference: 3.5.4.D, 4.1.4.A, 4.1.4.D.
4.1.4.E

2039D087244A4AAFBB97A15B9921EBEB.description:
Recognize ways that humans benefit from
the use of water resources (e.g.,
agriculture, energy, recreation).

77BBD563303C4340A6BCBDA0085439A6.description:
Identify the types and uses of Earth
materials for renewable, nonrenewable,
and reusable products (e.g., human-made
products: concrete, paper, plastics,
fabrics).

09C4A05A19F14949B219EB83BE66AD03.description:
Identify products and by-products of plants
and animals for human use (e.g., food,
clothing, building materials, paper
products).

A162023A480C41BDADBA9D0D53D7AC6A.description:
Identify the types and uses of Earth’s
resources.
Reference: 3.5.4.B, 3.5.4.D, 4.2.4.B,
4.8.4.D

87AC267A344744A485CB9C058439B96B.description:
Describe the composition of soil as
weathered rock and decomposed organic
remains.

7D662D278DA54EF4883EB2046AF7C274.description:
Identify various Earth structures (e.g.,
mountains, watersheds, peninsulas,
lakes, rivers, valleys) through the use of
models.

FF28D276497A4B0E98AA2E191A300DB9.description:
Describe how prominent Earth features in
Pennsylvania (e.g., mountains, valleys,
caves, sinkholes, lakes, rivers) were
formed.

B055388354DD4D608C654E922565C9CB.description:
Describe basic landforms in
Pennsylvania.
Reference: 3.5.4.A

854A9CFD14F348279ADA0B5BFDDACED3.description: Earth Features and Processes that Change Earth and Its Resources

AB7B562A28B844A1BC0B6EFDC17F1227.description:
Describe the position of an object by
locating it relative to another object or
a stationary background (e.g.,
geographic direction, left, up).

736112052934458EA131A90966E78F82.description:
Compare the relative movement of
objects or describe types of motion
that are evident (e.g., bouncing ball,
moving in a straight line, back and
forth, merry-go-round).

2E2950A75CC744A49439A947182F1420.description:
Describe changes in motion caused
by forces (e.g., magnetic, pushes or
pulls, gravity, friction).

155E473B5A014E278BC0C5764698DBF6.description:
Identify and describe different types of
force and motion resulting from these
forces, or the effect of the interaction
between force and motion.
Reference: 3.4.4.C, 3.6.4.C, 3.2.4.B

DFA5DD3B609F43ACB9BF41A447079A5D.description:
Identify characteristics of sound (e.g.,
pitch, loudness, reflection).

EC6640FD14884C359DED68966B976B86.description:
Recognize or illustrate simple direct
current series and parallel circuits
composed of batteries, light bulbs (or
other common loads), wire, and on/off
switches.

838F527A4F9F4CE89ED4204836F430A7.description:
Describe the flow of energy through
an object or system (e.g., feeling
radiant heat from a light bulb, eating
food to get energy, using a battery to
light a bulb or run a fan).

FB10D541C63A464DB2B172AEC92ED8F0.description:
Identify energy forms, energy transfer,
and energy examples (e.g., light,
heat, electrical).

BCEAF817E5CB4BE592EE0D47504D21CD.description:
Recognize basic energy types and
sources, or describe how energy can be
changed from one form to another.
Reference: 3.4.4.B, 3.4.4.C

18FCC9A735D5481DB11D86A71725B666.description: Forms, Sources, Conversion, and Transfer of Energy

C85CD9A83AE04B8DBCABF8CB0A2627B0.description:
Use physical properties [e.g., mass,
shape, size, volume, color, texture,
magnetism, state (i.e., solid, liquid,
and gas), conductivity (i.e., electrical
and heat)] to describe matter.

0DE921AE643D4232A0EAC5947F045467.description:
Describe observable physical properties
of matter.
Reference: 3.4.4.A, 3.2.4.B

BFFEEBD24F4043CD95D6A97730AC715B.description: Structure, Properties, and Interaction of Matter and Energy

529C3BC6EB00463E8C1DCA58D36DD4AE.description:
Describe the effects of pollution (e.g.,
litter) in the community.

C316767C20FB4C1BA6F03441B495AD76.description:
Identify major land uses in the urban,
suburban and rural communities (e.g.,
housing, commercial, recreation).

6D3EBB6D47204C4EB04F871270672C6E.description:
Identify biological pests (e.g., fungi –
molds, plants – foxtail, purple
loosestrife, Eurasian water milfoil;
animals – aphides, ticks, zebra mussels,
starlings, mice) that compete with
humans for resources.

928BB5575FEA4C9599C0784C42EF9700.description:
Describe the human dependence on the
food and fiber systems from production
to consumption (e.g., food, clothing,
shelter, products).

D8098F8AD93C4BADB745BB51E7BAF24F.description:
Identify everyday human activities (e.g.,
driving, washing, eating, manufacturing,
farming) within a community that
depend on the natural environment.

03DEC0E20B8B48FC9EA116785C8DE0C5.description:
Identify and describe human reliance on
the environment at the individual or the
community level.
Reference: 4.3.4.B, 4.4.4.B, 4.5.4.C,
3.8.4.C

C8506AE8C6E84A8686731B1C22E6C54B.description:
Explain and predict how changes in
seasons affect plants, animals, or daily
human life (e.g., food availability,
shelter, mobility).

54FBFD88DA6F47EBAF12EE4F3137AEF4.description:
Describe and predict how changes in the
environment (e.g., fire, pollution, flood,
building dams) can affect systems.

1628E284E62148CC967D9407CD11954F.description:
Describe what happens to a living thing
when its habitat is changed.

701B033E6AC549CF8E360502FA92E878.description:
Describe, explain, and predict change in
natural or human-made systems and the
possible effects of those changes on the
environment.
Reference: 4.2.4.C, 4.3.4.C, 4.6.4.C

EFC59F09AF774D6896D741554A21B809.description:
Describe interactions between living and
nonliving components (e.g. plants –
water, soil, sunlight, carbon dioxide,
temperature; animals – food, water,
shelter, oxygen, temperature) of a local
ecosystem.

1201D07785714211A6686A1FC37FCA9B.description:
Describe the living and nonliving
components of a local ecosystem (e.g.,
lentic and lotic systems, forest, cornfield,
grasslands, city park, playground).

62AAEF9443344A8A9E5783DA263B877F.description:
Identify and describe living and
nonliving things in the environment and
their interaction.
Reference: 4.6.4.A

CA436FC9BE904E03A20BFE70DF916A41.description:
S4.B.2.2.1 Identify physical characteristics (e.g.,
height, hair color, eye color, attached
earlobes, ability to roll tongue) that
appear in both parents and could be
passed on to offspring.

D1D07842D81641B4917275100E7F2A16.description:
Identify that characteristics are inherited
and, thus, offspring closely resemble
their parents.
Reference: 3.3.4.C, 4.7.4.A, 4.7.4.C

E885D067B9EB4DCDA34FC803EC512CD5.description:
Explain how specific adaptations can
help a living organism survive (e.g.,
protective coloration, mimicry, leaf
sizes and shapes, ability to catch or
retain water).

D9A121743DB045B29FB6547B119ECF87.description:
Identify characteristics for plant and
animal survival in different
environments (e.g., wetland, tundra,
desert, prairie, deep ocean, forest).

29C1F0058F394290A5499B451A40A4F0.description:
Identify and explain how adaptations
help organisms to survive.
Reference: 4.7.4.B

554BD965EB20438583ECD64D12D535F7.description:
Describe the life cycles of different
organisms (e.g., moth, grasshopper,
frog, seed-producing plant).

A1C9A2D50B71437DB30734F65F6638C4.description:
Describe how different parts of a living
thing work together to provide what
the organism needs (e.g., parts of
plants: roots, stems, leaves).

42A37F581F9A4EDBB04D2032428DD8CF.description:
Describe basic needs of plants and
animals (e.g., air, water, food).

7C2254085EEB4EF8A76F71D229D79D74.description:
Compare similar functions of external
characteristics of organisms (e.g.,
anatomical characteristics:
appendages, type of covering, body
segments).

D8B2C815217A44E0AB7CBEC1AC0F756E.description:
Identify life processes of living things
(e.g., growth, digestion, respiration).

1EEBC05283FE4101A3D4ACF0F31A8D8A.description:
Identify and describe similarities and
differences between living things and
their life processes.

Reference: 3.3.4.A, 3.3.4.B, 4.3.4.A,
4.3.4.C, 4.6.4.A

347A3D364D9641609ADEBAC55D1B08F5.description:
Identify and make observations about
patterns that regularly occur and
reoccur in nature.
Reference: 3.1.4.C, 3.2.4.B

9117AB7CD38C47CD847139219893923E.description:
Use appropriate, simple modeling
tools and techniques to describe or
illustrate a system (e.g., two cans and
string to model a communications
system, terrarium to model an
ecosystem).

6010C63E968F4F68BA747D6C6B7F5FF7.description:
Use models to make observations to
explain how systems work (e.g., water
cycle, Sun-Earth-Moon system).

C29E4BE584EE430EA4462B25A8F296F2.description:
Identify what different models
represent (e.g., maps show physical
features, directions, distances; globes
represent Earth; drawings of
watersheds depict terrain; dioramas
show ecosystems; concept maps
show relationships of ideas).

A9CAA102520346B99C64C6AB2B8FEDEA.description:
Use models to illustrate simple concepts
and compare the models to what they
represent.
Reference: 3.1.4.B, 4.3.4.C

A4BDAD260EEC4EE796F2DC6B6DF601F9.description:
Identify the parts of the food and fiber
systems as they relate to agricultural
products from the source to the
consumer.

1F4A1AA3221A4F4FA4A213D97660AA8F.description:
Categorize the parts of an ecosystem
as either living or nonliving and
describe their roles in the system.

7D78544D53EB42C88250FE7BE3190923.description:
Explain a relationship between the
living and nonliving components in a
system (e.g., food web, terrarium).

802C95EE5C1A453B8813D8D3B688059E.description:
Categorize systems as either natural
or human-made (e.g., ballpoint pens,
simple electrical circuits, plant
anatomy, water cycle).

9AB1BC7F161642F196ACD356435C8324.description:
Identify systems and describe
relationships among parts of a familiar
system (e.g., digestive system, simple
machines, water cycle).
Reference: 3.1.4.A, 4.4.4.C, 4.6.4.A,
4.6.4.B, 3.6.4.A, 3.6.4.B, 3.6.4.C

2DD1EE4B6D674D0780B529028F87BAD7.description:
Identify appropriate tools or
instruments for specific tasks and
describe the information they can
provide (e.g., measuring: length -
ruler, mass - balance scale, volume -
beaker, temperature - thermometer;
making observations: hand lens,
binoculars, telescope).

506F105BE40F4380A0C372980902E3D1.description:
Identify appropriate instruments for a
specific task and describe the
information the instrument can provide.
Reference: 3.7.4.A, 3.7.4.B

6E6FF4B6AC3648E4B6CEA10111D8A909.description:
State a conclusion that is consistent
with the information/data.

08005A7BC7AF455C983F8FE6431DDCEA.description:
Observe a natural phenomenon (e.g.,
weather changes, length of
daylight/night, movement of shadows,
animal migrations, growth of plants),
record observations, and then make a
prediction based on those
observations.

F3AFB2B76B8540EFBEDD081FB1C3801A.description:
Design and describe an investigation
(a fair test) to test one variable.

AB5D13552EB04A90A05CA1EBFDEBED20.description:
Generate questions about objects,
organisms, or events that can be
answered through scientific
investigations.

99087FDD3A494A56AA2C47BAC05A854D.description:
S4.A.2.1 Apply skills necessary to conduct an
experiment or design a solution to solve
a problem

C5ECA18B6C744E19AB438DEB4E4F167E.description: Processes, Procedures, and Tools of Scientific Investigations

216F9601B326431B95E0B417953BB885.description:
Provide examples, predict, or describe
how everyday human activities (e.g.,
solid waste production, food production
and consumption, transportation, water
consumption, energy production and
use) may change the environment.

9DE3EAB0FC91415E9B7019B3C70E768E.description:
Explain what happens to a living
organism when its food supply, access
to water, shelter, or space is changed
(e.g., it might die, migrate, change
behavior, eat something else).

505BCA9A8D844158A679460C1546EECE.description:
Observe and describe the change to
objects caused by temperature change
or light.

315798D4FE484A948AF3B3FE5E7EE54A.description:
Describe relative size, distance, or
motion.

5D095C9BDFC645369B6BF970501F87A7.description:
Observe and record change by using
time and measurement.

E3FBC730A71A491591B7A330F9DB3ADA.description:
Recognize and describe change in
natural or human-made systems and
the possible effects of those changes.
Reference: 3.1.4.C, 4.7.4.B, 4.8.4.A,
4.8.4.C

8C48021530C043E5AAB8FFB9858FC9A1.description:
Identify and describe examples of
common technological changes past to
present in the community (e.g., energy
production, transportation,
communications, agriculture, packaging
materials) that have either positive or
negative impacts on society or the
environment.

011EDEC3817C47F284B443CA8C7E5763.description:
Distinguish between a scientific fact and
an opinion, providing clear explanations
that connect observations and results
(e.g., a scientific fact can be supported
by making observations).

D389AACD3C174C2893870A966FEFF537.description:
Identify and explain the application of
scientific, environmental, or
technological knowledge to possible
solutions to problems.
Reference: 3.2.4.A, 3.2.4.C, 3.8.4.C
